About This Game

The Legacy of Star Wars Dark Forces™ and Star Wars® Jedi Knight lives on in the intense first-person action of Jedi Outcast.
  • As Kyle Katarn, agent of the New Republic, use your Lightsaber and the full power of the Force to combat a new evil plaguing the galaxy.
  • Wield over 8 Force abilities including the Jedi Mind Trick, Force Lightning and Force Grip.
  • Choose wisely from an arsenal of 13 weapons including disruptor rifle, thermal detonators, trip mines and Wookiee bowcaster.
  • Play on-line with 2-32 players or against a variety of AI Bots - and gain an additional 7 Force powers.
  • Test your skills in 24 single-player missions and in 6 different types of multiplayer games including Jedi Master, Holocron, Capture the Ysalamiri, Duel, Deathmatch and Capture the Flag.
  • Interact with legendary Star Wars characters such as Luke Skywalker and Lando Calrissian (featuring the voice of Billy Dee Williams as Lando.)
  • Developed by critically acclaimed Raven Studios and powered by the Quake III Arena engine.
READ MORE

System Requirements

Windows
Mac OS X
    • OS: Windows 2000, XP or Vista
    • Processor: Pentium II or Athlon 350 MHz
    • Memory: 64 MB
    • Graphics: 16 MB OpenGL compatible
    • DirectX®: 9.0c
    • Hard Drive: 800 MB
    • Sound: Direct X 8.0a
    • Multiplayer Requirements: Pentium II or Athlon 400MHz
    • OS: Mac OS X 10.7.5 (Lion), 10.8.5 (Mountain Lion), 10.9.5 (Mavericks), 10.10 (Yosemite)
    • Processor: 1.8 GHZ Intel chipset or faster
    • Memory: 512 MB or higher
    • Hard Disk Space: 1 GB
    • Video Card: ATI Radeon X1600 / NVidia Geforce 7300 / Intel HD 3000 (128 MB VRAM or higher)
    • Languages: English, French and German


    • Additional: Intel integrated video chipsets are not supported (GMA 950/X3100).

      This game is not supported on volumes formatted as Mac OS Extended (Case Sensitive)

Tiberius
307 products in account
117 reviews
Recommended
0.2 hrs on record
Posted: May 24
Personal rating: "Very Good" = 4/5

PROS:
+ good story
+ great gameplay
+ lightsaber combat
+ cool missions
+ Kyle Katarn
+ good mods

CONS:
- graphic & resolution options are outdated
- sometimes clunky lightsaber combat
- multiplayer is less visited (try Jedi Academy instead)
- sometimes confusing level design

Comment:
We again get to play as Kyle Katarn a jedi who does not really want to be one. The game is much more blaster/mine/rocket oriented at first, later the lightsaber comes into play too. While good the lightsaber animation could have used a bit polish as they are clunky sometimes. But they are still fun. Oh, and a lot of fun! With the dismemberment option on it feels like really having a powerful weapon you can cut every opponent with. And again we also get Force powers. The level design is done the classic Jedi Knight way - sometimes good and sometimes confusing. But the game remains enjoyable. The community of players who play online is weaker compared to Jedi Academy so I advise trying that out for MP. The mods are there for this game and use most of the potential so maybe take a look at some. This is a fine game for all who like Star Wars and/or have played the previous Jedi Knight games. I recommend this game!

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
3
hoimingmissile
494 products in account
52 reviews
Recommended
18.8 hrs on record
Posted: October 5
I'm sure this game was amazing at the time of release. You actually get to play as a Jedi with a lightsaber! And it's not just a click-to-melee-attack weapon, you can control the direction of the swing and stuff! The lightsaber combat would have been something new and innovative at the time.

Unfortunately, once again I've ended up playing a sequel before a previous installment. I played Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy already. I thought I'd done right this time, I mean, come on! That one is called Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy, this one is called Jedi Knight II : Jedi Outcast.

With that polished experience in mind, I found Outcast's lightsaber combat frustrating. I know how to use the lightsaber but time and time again I found myself getting sliced to pieces. The Reborn and the Dark Jedi are able to perform rapid and intricate slash maneuvers that you just cannot.

Speaking of frustrating, this game has some of the worst level design I've ever seen. I don't like it when games insist on holding my hand the whole time with large waypoint markers on linear maps but Jedi Outcast really went all the way in the other direction. Almost every mission found me stuck at some point because I simply couldn't figure out where to go next. Sometimes the place you're supposed to go next would turn out to be a tiny grate IN THE CEILING in a non-descript room that you'd already passed through earlier in the level. Sometimes it's an inconspicuous hole that's off to the side of the path, but the path continues for several more encounters with no indication so you wind up fighting through one or two more entire map sections before finally ending up in a place with walls you can't climb and doors that don't open, wondering if there's a switch that you missed somewhere.

Ending this on a high note, the plot was good and the sounds of the Star Wars universe are always a pleasure to listen to. The music, the beeps and whirs of panels, even the sound of blaster fire, it's great.
Read More

Adolf Stalin
297 products in account
59 reviews
Recommended
9.2 hrs on record
Posted: May 21
I personally disliked Jedi Outcast years ago (I played it in 2006 or so for the first time) and after these years I still have mixed feelings about this game.
It's not a good shooter. Compared to Dark Forces 2 (I managed to run it off Steam some time ago) it's bland and irritiating. Heck, even compared to Dark Forces 1 it's lacking, and Dark Forces 1 has an auto-aim. Probably because weapons in this game (except sniper rifle and basic blaster) are so inaccurate and their power feels off it doesn't feel much different from having the auto-aim in the first game in the series. Also, being more of a 3rd person action game, the movement while in 1st person mode will cost you life many times after slipping off the ledge.

Yeah, this game is all about lightsaber ♥♥♥♥. But it's hard to recommend Jedi Outcast now, since Jedi Academy is plain better in that matter. While Dark Forces 2 balanced shooter and slasher gameplay pretty well, Jedi Outcast sacrificed shooting in favor of lightsaber ♥♥♥♥ (after all these years of terrible lightsabers sounds and their exploitation everywhere I grew to hate lightsabers and everything connected with them). I dunno - compared to Jedi Academy, saber fighting with AI gets my nerves off. Maybe the multiplayer is the reason I had remembered it well, up until I launched it now. While in Jedi Academy I enjoyed almost an every lightsaber fight, in Jedi Outcast I'm willing cut my wrists fighting Reborns or bosses. It's significantly less accurate than Dark Forces 2 saber fighting (and shooting for that matter).

Level design is pretty good. It's not amazing, but it's not a walk down the corridor all the way. The first levels in the game are the best ones, with the exception of Nar Shaddaa (the only level where the shooting is bearable), while the rest of them (♥♥♥♥ing Bespin) are just a show-off arenas connected with corridors to force more lightsaber fighting and jumping around every corner. At the end of the day, it's nothing to write home about, and the lack of map is sometimes annoying (the previous games have maps).

And there's the story. It's a typical expanded universe's mania of writing (stuff from there mostly exists solely to make money from sad, exceptional people who can't define themselves without connecting to a commercial diarrhea) rubbish that destroyed the original Star Wars theme,

It's not a bad game, not at all, but compared to every other title in the series - it's an obviously sub-par title which got stuck between genres. This game works best on cheats on, off the campaign and off the multiplayer, messing with force powers, cutting enemies in pieces.
